Trade deficits are a feature, not a bug, of a system of voluntary exchange. Only in a (theoretical but not possible) system of total government control and central planning could trade deficits be eliminated‚Äîand that would be a world of universal slavery and extreme poverty.
This basic economic concept applies to international transactions just as it applies to neighborhood transactions.

Trade deficits do not mean that anyone is taking advantage of anyone else. The grocery store will have a trade deficit with a farmer or supplier, just as you have a trade deficit with the grocery store.
When any customer buys more from any business than the business buys from the customer, the customer has a trade deficit with the business.
When you buy more from the grocery store than the grocery store buys from you, you have a trade deficit with the grocery store.

Trade wars are bad for consumers, workers, farmers, businesses, practically everyone. People will pay more for basic goods and workers will lose their jobs. Instead of making bad, unilateral trade policy on a whim, the U.S. should be working with our allies to improve the system.

Broad tariffs @realdonaldtrump is threatening would adversely impact our allies and many domestic manufacturers who would pay more for materials. They may also lead to retaliation from other countries against U.S. made goods and services. This will lead to a trade war.
In many sectors, including steel and aluminum, China has pursued trade-distorting policies that should be addressed. However, Section 232 is NOT the right tool.
Secretary Mattis also notes in his memo that the military currently uses only 3% of domestic production, so @DeptofDefense does not believe there is a risk of not having domestic capacity.

Everyone agrees that the capacity of producing steel and aluminum domestically is important to national security, as Secretary Mattis notes in this memo to Commerce: https://www.commerce.gov/sites/commerce.gov/files/department_of_defense_memo_response_to_steel_and_aluminum_policy_recommendations.pdf
